title: Australia bans children under 16 from using social media apps
snippets: The world is watching as Australia becomes the first country to ban under-16s from social media. Adults support it but children consider the ban an attack on their rights, which will isolate some of the most vulnerable.
The world’s first social media ban for under 16’s starts this week – will it succeed?
Australia's social media ban for children takes effect in world first Reuters
Australia social media ban set to take effect, sparking a global crackdown Reuters

Accounts held by users under 16 must be removed on apps that include TikTok, Facebook, Instagram, X, YouTube, Snapchat, Reddit, Kick, Twitch and Threads under ban How is Australia’s social media ban affecting you and your family? The social media ban explained: everything you need to know Australia
The measure is one of the most sweeping efforts in the world to safeguard children from the harms of the platforms.
The country is barring children under 16 from social media, with a sweeping federal law that is one of the first attempts at a nationwide regulation.
titles: Australia social media ban: Children feel isolated, ignored
Will a social media ban for Australian teens work?

Australia social media ban set to take effect, sparking a global crackdown - Reuters

constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful insights into the impact of social media bans on children’s mental health. It increases awareness about a significant issue, but it doesn't report on any solutions or improvements.
summary: Australia has enacted a federal law banning children under 16 from using social media platforms, including TikTok, Facebook, Instagram, X, YouTube, Snapchat, Reddit, Kick, Twitch, and Threads. The law, which took effect this week, requires accounts held by users under 16 to be removed. Supporters say it aims to protect children, while critics argue it may isolate vulnerable youths. This is the world’s first nationwide social media ban for under-16s.

title: Elephant scientist Iain Douglas Hamilton dies at age 83

summary: Iain Douglas-Hamilton, a British conservationist and scientist, has died at age 83. He was recognized as a leading authority on African elephant behavior and dedicated his life to their study and preservation. His work significantly contributed to protecting elephants from poaching and advancing global conservation efforts.
